"I became interested in computers and transistors at
college," Robert Pike recalls. "In fact, my senior
project was building a small computer. So, when I
graduated from the University of Maine in June, 1955,
I naturally turned to the computer field. IBM, recognized as a leader in this expanding electronics area,
looked like a good place for me."
Bob Pike began his IBM career as a Technical Engineer, starting with a training program that lasted several months. Then, asked to select the work area of his
choice, he picked the Semi-Conductor Device Development Group in Research. "My first assignment," he
says, "was to plot various electrical and physical device parameters for a large number of transistors in
the form of graphs or histograms in order to obtain
correlation coefficients of the device characteristics."

Bob Pike was promoted to Associate Physicist in
December, 1956. His present assignment is leading a

high-power PNP drift transistors. "We use a process

FOR BETTER OR FOR WORSE
The first, thought that comes into our minds upon entering
college is, of course, marriage. But how many of us go about
seeking mates,as I like to call them,in a truly scientific manner?
Not many, you may be sure.
So let us today make a scientific survey of the. two principal
causes of marriage—personality need and propinquity.
Personality need means that we choose mates because they
possess certain qualities that complete and fulfill our own personalities. Take, for example, the case of Alanson Duck.
As a freshman Alanson made a fine scholastic record, played
varsity scrabble, and was president of his class. One would
think that Manson was a totally fulfilled man. But he was not.
There was something lacking in his life, something vague and
indefinable that was needed to make his personality complete.
Then one day Alanson discovered what it was. As he was
walking out of his class in Flemish pottery, a fetching coed
named Grace Ek offered him a handsome red and white pack
and said, "Marlboro?"
"Yes!" he cried, for all at once he knew what he had been
needing to round out his personality—the hearty fulfillment of
Marlboro Cigarettes, the soul-repairing mildness of their fine
tobaceo, the easy draw of their unparalleled filter, the ease and
convenience of their crushproof flip-top box. "Yes, I will take a
Marlboro!" cried Alanson. "And I will also take you to wife
if you will have me!"
"La!" she exclaimed, throwing her apron over her face. But
after a while she removed it and they were married..Today
they live happily in Baffin Land where Alanson is with an
otter-glazing firm and Grace is a bookie.
Propinquity, the.second principal cause of marriage, simply
means closeness. Put a boy and a girl close together for a sustained period of time and their proximity will certainly ripen
into love and their love into marriage. A perfect example is
the case of Fafnir Sigafoos.
While a freshman at Louisiana State University, Fafnir was
required to crawl through the .Big Inch pipeline as part of his
fraternity initiation. He entered the pipe at Baton Rouge and,
alone and joyless, he proceeded to crawl 'north.
As he passed Lafayette, Indiana, be was agreeably surprised
to be joined by a comely girl named Mary Alice Isinglass, a
Purdue freshman, who, oddly enough„ had to crawl through
the Big Inch as part of her sorority initiation.

With a few silent exceptions, the relations between
the Dormitory Students' Representative Council and the
rank and file of the dormitories are either mildly negative
or non-existent.
We refer not just to the rather startling instances of
vandalism and destruction that appear occasionally, but
to the general estrangement between the elected leaders
and the led. Unless the representative takes the initiative
and attempts to develop something like a house spirit,
the result in most houses is that he develves into a more
or less disliked suppressor of hall lacrosse, baseball,
hockey, soccer or ouiji games and dispenser of light bulbs.
"We aren't policemen," said One representative. Another, when asked what the purpose behind the Council
is, said simply that it is to ensure good living conditions
in the dormitories. And this, we think, is exactly where
the failure lies.
Here the DSRC can implement Dean Shaffer's
plans for the dormitory. By providing the leadership
necessary to allow for letting off steam by the denizens
of the dormitories, it can make the dorms in fact a home
away from home.
The bleakness of the rooms in the houses can be alleviated, with much lessening of expense to the City of
Baltimore Department of Signs, by opening a store perhaps in the basement to sell rugs, curtains, brooms and
furnishings for same—cheaply. Or at least sponsoring
a Student Shop effort in the same direction.
We commend the organization for its efforts to initiate and continue the interhouse athletic program, the
dances, and a few student rallies. But many of the projects
bog down, not through the lack of support of the students, but of the representatives themselves. It is noteworthy that in houses with representatives who are interested in their jobs, these projects and many private
ones have received excellent support.
We suspect that a good deal of the famous Hopkins
apathy is at least equally shared by the individual representatives.

So let us today make a scientific survey of the. two principal
causes of marriage—personality need and propinquity.
Personality need means that we choose mates because they
possess certain qualities that complete and fulfill our own personalities. Take, for example, the case of Alanson Duck.
As a freshman Alanson made a fine scholastic record, played
varsity scrabble, and was president of his class. One would
think that Manson was a totally fulfilled man. But he was not.
There was something lacking in his life, something vague and
indefinable that was needed to make his personality complete.
Then one day Alanson discovered what it was. As he was
walking out of his class in Flemish pottery, a fetching coed
named Grace Ek offered him a handsome red and white pack
and said, "Marlboro?"
"Yes!" he cried, for all at once he knew what he had been
needing to round out his personality—the hearty fulfillment of
Marlboro Cigarettes, the soul-repairing mildness of their fine
tobaceo, the easy draw of their unparalleled filter, the ease and
convenience of their crushproof flip-top box. "Yes, I will take a
Marlboro!" cried Alanson. "And I will also take you to wife
if you will have me!"
"La!" she exclaimed, throwing her apron over her face. But
after a while she removed it and they were married..Today
they live happily in Baffin Land where Alanson is with an
otter-glazing firm and Grace is a bookie.
Propinquity, the.second principal cause of marriage, simply
means closeness. Put a boy and a girl close together for a sustained period of time and their proximity will certainly ripen
into love and their love into marriage. A perfect example is
the case of Fafnir Sigafoos.

required to crawl through the .Big Inch pipeline as part of his
fraternity initiation. He entered the pipe at Baton Rouge and,
alone and joyless, he proceeded to crawl 'north.
As he passed Lafayette, Indiana, be was agreeably surprised
to be joined by a comely girl named Mary Alice Isinglass, a
Purdue freshman, who, oddly enough„ had to crawl through
the Big Inch as part of her sorority initiation.

Although his squad has less

Tom Biddison, All-Maryland
attackman from Baltimore City
College and Jim Greenwood, AllPrep athlete from McDonogh,
head a squad on which almost
two-thirds of the candidates have
seen previous varsity action in
prep school.
Baltimore's Best Player
Biddison, Greenwood and Tom
Fitzhugh, a midfield star at Baltimore Poly, starred for the
North squad in the Cocoanut
Bowl lacrosse game, which was
held this past winter in conjunction with a lacrosse clinic in

in scoring with four goals.

(Annapolis), Skip Leet (St.

Latin), Frank Weiss (McDonogh), Ely Fishkin (Poly), Jim

Greenwood,
Mal
